reviewText:
I love the game.   The subject matter is something I am really interested in (Heroes and comics) and given how badly most comics are written these days (new 52,,, yuck) this is a breath of fresh air.    This is like the movie Sky High, which I also loved (wish they had made a sequel) I have logged a lot of hours trying to get all of the   sub plots (and trying to pick which one will be my starting point for the next installment).

Be advised, this game is exactly what it says.   Text based, with only a few images at the start and no music.  Other than that, it is a lot like Long Live the Queen and Magic Diary.    I am impressed with how much dialog is included, it is like a Choose Your Own Adventure ... novel.   I think it (by in large) avoids the pit falls of the Choose your Own Adventure books,  if you really think about the choices and the characters... the responses make sense.   For the cost... it is a real steal.

I recently got a little burned following Life Is Strange, but I think the developer of this game will come through with a lot of endings at the end that will please everyone.   I think the problem with Life is Strange is that producing a bunch of endings when you have voice talent, music, and graphical images, and a lot of overhead,  is very difficult.   I have really high hopes that in the end of this game, if you make the right choices, some endings may actually be very rewarding.  I wish it had a few more images, for key plot twists... but it is still fun to use your imagination.

This game marks the sixth text choice game that I've played.
Compared to the consequence systems of the others, the choices given in this entry are much more intricate and varied, giving way to a more enjoyable experience.

Pros:
- Tons of ways to play out your character regarding academics, image, and relationships.
- Fun twist on the entire super hero genre story wise: You enter the game as a non-zenith (no powers) accepted into a community college super hero school aiming to seek revenge for the death of your father.
- For once, the decisions you make have a varied impact on the story and what you can or can't do.
- A nice little cliffhanger and a few choices that allow you to set up what your character wants to do after the events of the last chapter.

reviewText:
SynopsisCommunity College Hero: Trial by Fire is an interactive fiction game where you play a budding young hero who goes to a community college with a brand spanking new hero training program. It's full of drama, mystery, intrigue, and romance. This is marketed as Issues 1–4 of a 12-issue miniseries, so perhaps there is yet quite a bit to come. I've played through the game several times, created wildly diverse protagonists, and have so far unlocked over 80% of the achievements, so I feel as though I've seen most of the possible choices you can make in the game.

Pros:Diverse gender and sexuality options, including non-binary gender and asexual orientation. This is so rare in games that I decided to play this game based on this fact alone. There are also numerous romance options, which can be a lot of fun.
Well-written, complex characters. Other than a few minor characters, each character seems detailed, multifaceted, and mysterious. In true superhero fashion, it seems that everyone has a deep, dark secret, including the faculty of the college.
Stats. Unlike other interactive fiction, this incorporates RPG elements by giving my character statistics and allowing me to base my decisions on them, as well as influencing what sorts of decisions I can make and how successful they are likely to be. Decisions I make during the course of the story also modify my stats, which include my relationship scores with the various characters.
Cons:Railroading. This is my biggest complaint about the game. While there are lots of options, many of which influence various outcomes, sometimes it seems like none of the choices make any difference, particularly in the final act. I understand the need to advance the narrative towards a particular end, but the mark of a truly skillful author is to make it feel like my choices guided me there, even if the outcome was predestined.
Not fully polished. I may be rather pedantic, but errors in spelling, grammar, and punctuation tend to jump out at me. There weren't many, but in a game that is essentially 100% text, it becomes all the more important to catch them before releasing the game. Also, there were occasionally some logical inconsistencies in the text based on certain choices I had made. None of these inconsistencies made much of a difference to the plot, but they did pull me out of the immersion at times.
Clunky interface. Attempting to navigate the various menus was awkward at times and felt somewhat unintuitive. Of particular note is the inability to return directly to the stats screen from one of its sub-categories (Relationships, Academics, or Resources). In addition, while I can save my game once I complete it, the system for doing so is confusing, and I hope that in a sequel, I will have some way to access a list of the save files, because it is doubtful that I will remember the file names that I chose.
Final ThoughtsAs a piece of interactive fiction, this game is quite good. Despite my criticisms, my experience was positive overall, and I do recommend investing money in this product to support the developers. I'm very eager to see how the story plays out, and given the price of this game, there is little reason not to get it if you are a fan of the genre. In fact, there is a demo version which you should consider playing first, just to see if you will like it. Have fun!

reviewText:
Let me preface by saying I love most Choice of Games (and Hosted Games, its oftentimes less clever but sometimes still funny younger brother.)  This story appears to be published under Hosted Games, where you can submit your story to Choice of Games, and they can publish it if they think it's good enough (Stories published under Choice of Games are commissioned by professional writers.) Hosted Games can be good. Zombie Exodus is excellent, go try it. But I recognise that these authors are not professional, so I can forgive lesser quality for more creativity.

This story, however, is a disappointment on both fronts. There's no other way to put it: the writing is terrible. You can on ly play 3 cliched archetypes. I can't even immerse myself into the archetypes because the dialogue is awkward. I want to choose a dialogue option that fits my character but the lines are so bad I cannot imagine anyone saying them. The story introduces a whole bunch of characters without much characterisation at once. There are some scenes that might be considered technically good, like the early terrorism scene and the park capture-the-flag scene, but they're not worth it.

The writer should not be charging money for this fanfiction-quality of writing, let alone charging more per-installment (this is only the first installment!) than the all-around excellent Zombie Exodus. Choice of Games shouldn't let this quality be published under their name. I bought this game without demo-ing the game because I trusted the company to do quality assurance, because they made great games like Choice of Robots, Choice of Romance, and Heroes Rise. I'm just... seriously disappointed.

P.S. If you want a better superhero/villain game, try Heroes Rise or Diabolical. If you want powers in a school setting try Psy High. They are much, much better.

reviewText:
First point of the review: This game has a free demo (insert rant on how demos seem to have mostly replaced by DRMs and on what that says about the game-making industry). Go play it. It's what sold me on buying the game.

I'd played a COG gamedemo before (Tin Star) and I skipped on buying it, as it didn't catch my interest. This game? This? I played the demo and when I reached the end I immediately bought it because I just had to know what would happen next. What happens next? It gets better, that's what happens next.

The NPCs are fun and believable (well, for superpowered people, anyways) - a few of them look stereotypical at first look, but most of those do reveal hidden depths if you befriend them and probe deeper. The story is great and hints of even bigger things to come. It gets slightly railroady at times (I still don't get why I have to be rude to Hi-Jinx, for instance), but that's unavoidable in a computer game, and there's no blatant plot-induced stupidity forced on you. And I probably chose the most boring path midway through the game. I'll have to replay it. Speaking of which...

This game has incredible replayability - with branching paths and mutually exclusive options, you'll have to play it about a (Diabolical) Dozen times to get all the information. There's half a dozen romanceable characters, too, if you're interested in that, of both genders, and they don't care what gender you are. And then there's trying to optimise the paths you've already chosen, which will likely lead to another couple of replays.

Fair warning, it's part 1 of, apparently 4? It's issues 1-4 of 12, so that's what I'm assuming. This means it'll take you some downtime and probably 4 times the stated price to get the whole story. The author has assured people that he's already hard at work on CCH2 and that he has no intention of pulling a Robert Jordan, a George Martin, or, heavens forbid, a Valve on us.

For those that care, you also get to suckerpunch people.

9/10 - if in a future installment I get to turn Professor Sleazemarble into a rockery, then 12/10

Dude, seriously, demo - go play it, it's free.

alright, so, i just played through one run-through of this game. naturally, there's gonna be SPOILERS in this review, so if ya don't want to know things, juuuuust don't click the spoiler text, kay?

so i played as my own hero, sans seraph. pretty decent. really easy to get on the bad side of some people (seriously, loosen up, tress) and never get to their good side (considering that the only thing bad i did was flirt with her to begin with....heh. whoops. guess i didn't in-tress her, even though i made the attempt to be nice afterwards, she just kinda...blew me off.), but i managed to find a good balance between hanging out with uni and dirty girl. uni ended up being my favorite, surprisingly. too bad she leaves at the end. hopefully i can still keep in contact with her in the sequel, provided i play again and don't wuss out of kissing her so i can actually get on her path.

i saw a few typos here and there too but it wasn't enough to take me out of the experience, really, along with a few missing words in sentences. i can't remember exactly, but it happened once or twice - not a big deal, though. didn't impact my experience too much.

overall it's a really good game and i'm looking forward to the sequel.

You, first off, sort of create your own hero by what your real name is, your hero name, what you wear for your uniform, what sort of personality you are. There are probably going to be plenty of people drawing parallels between this series and the HeroRise series, so I'm going to go ahead and jump on the bandwagon and give you my take on it.  Since this is just the first installment, I'm only going to compare it to HR: Prodigy.

So to start off, you'll be happy to know that this is not a complete rehash of HR: P.  CCH is its own thing entirely, and while there are similarities (tragic backstory involving parent(s) that was/were shunned by society, mystery involving villain with unknown origins and motives, power-play between different hero factions) I feel like those are general tropes that superhero stories have been using a lot recently.

As a whole I think HR: P has a better all-around story.  TbF is spending a more of its time getting you ready for the sequels and I feel like there was less resolved at the end than in HR: P.  If you only wanted to play one game and have no intention of playing the whole series, HR is probably the better choice.  TbF also had a LOT of characters, which made it harder to get to know them all.  You'll have to do several playthroughs if you want to understand all of them, whereas HR kept it more condensed which allowed more development for the characters it had.

That being said, I did thoroughly enjoy this game.  While it did feel crowded at times, I do still think that all the characters were developed well and had there own unique personalities.  The environment really did feel like a college, which helped CCH differentiate itself from other Choice of Games hero stories.  The plot was engaging, the mystery was fun, and it did a great job at getting me excited for the next installment.

So while I do prefer HR: P, I feel like CCH: TbF has done a fantastic job at making its own thing, and I can't wait for Eric Moser to publish the next several chapters.

Plus it was a thousand times better than HeroProject: Redemption Season.  So there's that.
